They also have a pretty large and super fun (read: girly) cocktail menu, and since they are tropical in nature, it's totally okay to imbibe at any time of the day! That's how that works, right? Riiight...?

They have a fried chicken night on Thursdays that a lot of people like. Kinda makes me wish I liked fried chicken so I could try it but I'm weird like that!

I love Kaya.  It is a cool place with an interesting atmosphere.  I've dined here several times and have thoroughly enjoyed my experience every single time.  
It is a long, thin restaurant with a slightly larger room in the back.  When you walk in, there is a long bar on one wall and a long series of tables along the other wall.  The tables are easily configured so that you can have parties of two or move tables together for larger parties.  I've come with parties as large as eight and they were accommodating for any size party.
The menu has a variety of options and although it changes seasonally, there are some items that seem to be staples and always on the menu.  There are a wide variety of appetizers, really something that will please every palate.  What I like is that although entrees are on the pricier side ($20+ each) there are appetizers that are substantial enough that you can make a meal from one or two of them.  
My favorite entre I've had was a steak with chili rellenos.  It was packed full of flavor and a pretty substantial portion size.  In terms of appetizers, my favorites have been the yucatan bean dip and conch fritters.  Both are unique and full of flavor.
The drink menu offers many tropical options and standard fare as well.  I did find the drinks a bit overpriced for the size you get, but they were very tasty.
Kaya is an enjoyable dining experience and I will be back/

Kaya is a great experience in the Strip District of Pittsburgh. The atmosphere and service is always on point and the service is excellent. The menu is interesting, and very unique. Try the bean dip, it's magnificent. The cocktails are excellent too, more so in the summer than winter.

Too bad there is no 0 ** ratings.
We had Sat. lunch here. 
Ordered:  Kaya Chips with Mango-Tomatillo Salsa, Caribbean Rainbow Salad, Todo En Uno Cuban Sandwich with Gazpacho and spicy slaw.
Except of enormously huge portions there is nothing positive to write about. The food was tasting just awful, and who needs huge portions of tasteless food? Definitely not us, so more than a half of it was left on the plates.
The service was not any better then food. LOOONG waits for everything.
The value was not good either. It was one of those VERY RARE cases when we didn't want to leave the tips greatly NOT deserved.
Where these "positive" reviews come from I don't know, but needless to say we're surely NOT coming back.

Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh. Each visit I start with their amazing black bean dip, which comes with delicious chips. It has the perfect amount of spice. I've had several meals from their burger, the pulled pork quesadilla, and their Jamaican jerk chicken. The service is impeccable, and I've never had a bad experience. Cheers to Kaya!

In general, a nice place and we had a very friendly server. I would probably give it a 3.5 if that was an option. And I would put it in the second-tier classes of good restaurant in Pittsburgh. It is a good experience but not excellent. This was my third time being there and all three times ordered their big salad but this time with Tofu. The option without Tofu is definitely better.  The tofu was quite without any taste and somewhat destroyed the salad experience. Also, the iceberg lettuce in the salad does not contribute to much of a great experience. Overall, I had a better memory of the dish that my recent experience.

Went for the monthly(Third wednesday of every month) seasonal vegetarian prix-fixe and it was wonderful. I can't give much more because I went a long time ago, but I will definitely return here in the future to update my review.

Found this place by using Yelp, of course, while wandering the streets of Pittsburgh. The BEST soft shell crab I've ever had! Loved the Caribbean theme, reminded me of the island that I love! Great atmosphere, food and staff!

I've been trying to review Kaya for an embarrassing length of time. I'd start a draft, realize I wasn't doing this place justice, then I'd start over. I realize I'll never be able to summarize how incredible Kaya is, or how delighted it has made me over the years, but I can't leave the Pittsburgh area without attempting to express just how much I love Kaya.
There aren't enough available adjectives to describe the food. I always start the party with one of their magical appetizers. The lentil and corn beignets are always impressive, lightly fried and served with a wonderfully spicy green curry sauce. Perfect for sharing. The Yucatan hot bean dip with homemade chips may be the most addictive item on the menu. The rich, spicy-ish, slightly cheesy dip with those magnificently salty chips will make it difficult to carry on a conversation with your dining companions. You'll be too busy hollowing out that tasty dip. The tofu cracklins are enough to astound even the non-vegetarians with the chipotle honey BBQ flavor and crispy texture. The field green salad is served with possibly the world's best salad dressing. This lime cilantro vinaigrette should be bottled and sold. To me, specifically. With all of the amazing vegetarian appetizers, it's almost too difficult to save enough room for an entree.  But I do. Oooohhhh, I do.
Jerked. Tofu. Tacos. If Kaya only had one item on their menu and this was it, it would still be my favorite restaurant. Ever. Fresh, soft, warm tortillas with a mind blowing cilantro cream sauce, avocado, a cabbage slaw, peppers and tofu prepared so expertly you'll swear you might cry...but that's probably the jerk seasoning talking. Your order comes with three tacos, and they are large. The third one is perfect for lunch the following day, although you'll be sad you aren't actually eating it at Kaya. The Jamaican green curry vegetable dish is a spicy little number with saffron rice, potatoes, squash, peas, and pineapple. Each time you get a fork full with that pineapple covered in the creamy, fiery green curry, your eyes just might roll back in your head with delight. The veggie Kaya burger is a wondrous experience. Homemade veggie patty (no phoning it in with some frozen Boca burger here!), avocado, pickles, tomato, chihuahua cheese and a sunny side up egg. It's messy. It's large. It's heavenly. And with a side of sweet potato fries it's perfection. 
The brunch menu seems to change often. Just know that you can't go wrong with any of the Sunday offerings, whether it be chocolate chip waffles or huevos rancheros. Just be sure to try the Vampiro cocktail, with tequila and grapefruit juice. 
Cocktails at Kaya are inventive and exciting. Cocktail menu changes quite often and during happy hour everything is half price! My favorite drink I've experienced here has to be the mango Mai Thai. For the winter months, they've traded mango for pomegranate. Which is just fine with this girl. The cherry spritzer served in a champagne flute with it's bitter sweetness is hard not to love. The mojito is a reliable favorite. The dark and stormy is stupendous. The bartenders are very skilled and it makes all the difference in the world.
Service is always on point. Nice servers, who seem to remember us as we are there so often. I'm not sure if Chaz still waits tables at Kaya as I haven't seen him in quite sometime. He was the greatest, most knowledgable, friendliest server I've had in my life, and we'd always get excited when we knew he was waiting on us. If you happen to see him, consider yourself lucky. And please, tip him well. 
The vibe at Kaya is casual, Caribbean and inviting. Always a decent crowd at the bar sampling those stunning cocktails and ample amounts of seating. The lights are low, the music is funky, and I'm probably in a booth resisting the urge to lick my plate. 
Kaya is not only my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. It's my favorite restaurant ANYWHERE. An exceptional dining experience all around. I could never do it justice with words. You'll have to check it out for yourself!

I went to Kaya on 2/27 around 9pm.  All of the food was overcooked for each person's meal.  I ordered the conch fritters (and soup) and my boyfriend order the ribs for appetizer and salmon entree.  My conch fritters had such a crunch that the sauce provided was hardly sufficient for one fritter.  My food was so overcooked that the person next to me (not in my party) who also ordered conch fritters couldn't help but tell me he was in the same boat!  His food also was overcooked.

When my boyfriend's ribs were overcooked, I really urged him to return them to the kitchen.  However, he was reluctant out of fear that his food might be spat in.

I really wanted to impress my boyfriend for his birthday, but sadly it just wasn't possible with the look of disappointment he just couldn't hide.  I really had high hopes for this visit because I had a great one about a year ago.  But sadly something has changed.

Someone reached out to me to "remedy the situation" but never did.  I can assure you this is a place of false promises.  I wouldn't trust them for decent food or good service.

I haven't had anything I didn't like from this place yet. We've been here for brunch and dinners ordering the chicken and waffle, jerk chicken, corn beignets, tuna taco, kaya chips, and skirt steak. They also serve great cocktails and for brunch they offer bellini!! 

Try to make a reservation as the hostess here is pretty bad at managing tables. We came for brunch and got seated at the bar, which was fine. There were 6 of us, so it was a little harder to talk when there was an empty table for 6 with a reservation card on it. We had ordered, eaten and sat for a little while and never saw that party come in by the time we left.

I have been to Kaya a couple of times now and every single time I loved it so far. The staff is so friendly and knowledgeable and everyone always seems to have a smile on their face! Stepping into the place, it's dark and cozy. It's not the biggest place, but it gives it its flair and I love the decorations.

I have tried a couple of appetizers and seem to always order the "conch hush puppies" with spicy habanero aioli and mango! Absolutely delicious with a nice kick to it. Also, if you do love seafood you really cannot go wrong with the tropical paella. The serving was huge for the price at lunch time and very filling with a very generous portion of shrimp, scallops, mussels etc. It also has some nicely flavored chicken and chorizo in it. Definitely one of the best paella I have had so far in Pittsburgh. We have also tried the Flank Steak Cemita and what can I say? The meat was tender and oh so good. I have expected a "normal burger", but what I got was so much better than this. With all the food we tried the white sangria, which was very fruity and on the sweeter side, but delicious.

I have been here at dinner times and it can get very busy in here difficult to get a seat, but trust me, even if you have to wait, it's going to be worth it!

I really love this restaurant.  I think they have some really, really awesome and unique food.  My parents live close by, so this is often a place that we drop in at on the spur of the moment.  The burger is so good, loaded high with delicious things.  I love the fish tacos!!!!  One time we went and sat outside, but there was a really bad smell coming from the street, which threw off my whole meal, so I probably wouldn't sit outside again.  It does get pretty crowded during prime time, but if you go a little early or a little late, you can usually sneak in without a reservation.  I am really glad they have quality places like this in this part of town.

One word for Kaya: Delightful! 
Been there for a dinner date on a Friday evening and I was surprised they took reservations. Our waitress that evening was extremely helpful. We have food restrictions, and she was nice enough to go over all the dishes which suited it. We LOVED the chicken wings (really spicy, so watch out!) We had the Seasonal Vegetable Paella, which was really nice. For drinks, I had the margharita special they had, which I felt wasn't strong. +1 for their service and food quality! Would go there again.
Great food. Awesome atmosphere. Outdoor seating available. Good margaritas. A+. Try the burger.

This visit was my second time here. Came for brunch with my friend and had a big burrito brunch coupon! Food and drinks were great, hostess service was kind of lacking. We called ahead to see about the wait and were left on hold and when we arrived, we stood at the door for a few minutes without anyone greeting us until we decided to just sit at the bar. So that is the reason for 4 stars instead of 5. I had a brunch entree that I would describe as brunch nachos. It had chorizo and a fried over easy egg on top. It was so good and different with the Caribbean flavors! Bloody Mary's were also good with pepper vodka!
I always stop in here before going to events at Heinz Hall or The Benedum. The food is amazing and the tropical decor makes you feel like you are on vacation.

Checked this place out yesterday for lunch  and was very satisfied with my time here. The atmosphere was very fun and it seemed like they put a lot of effort into their decor. 

The first thing that I usually notice is how many vegetarian options a restaurant has, and Kaya did not let me down! It is rare that I can find so many things that I am able to eat that I actually have a difficult choice deciding. 

I ended up getting the tempura avocado tacos. It had jalapenos, carrots, cucumber and cilantro. I also got a side of the sweet potato fries, which I have to say I did not love. They were just too oily. The tacos were great though! Very filling. The only problem was I asked the waiter if they were spicy at all and he said no, which was a lie! Twas spicy! It seemed like everything might be a little spicy here, however, so beware if you do not like a bit of a kick.

This is an amazing place!  Great atmosphere, very clean, beautiful bar, and most importantly, great food!

Shoot for the fish tacos; yum!!!

The only reason I didn't rate this a 5 star was due to the service being quite slow and lackluster. Other than that, GO NOW!

Huge fan of Pittsburgh but always get suckered into eating at some trendy place like that famous sandwich shop around the corner.

Words of advice:

Eat at Kaya at least once.  
It has a great ambiance to it. 
Nicely stocked bar, great service

I ordered Jerk chicken wings.  Huge chicken wings with a cool dipping sauce on the side...great start to a huge meal.

I washed down my wings with a Cuban sandwich.  Lots of taste to this thing.  Beats a sandwich with French fries on it any day.

Reasonable prices, food seems fresh and its in a great area.

Creative Menu and Delicious Food!

We were visiting Pittsburgh for the weekend and were so happy to discover this amazing restaurant in the Strip District.  What a creative menu inspired by the Caribbean Islands and South America!  

We ordered the Corn & Lentil Beignets with green curry sauce for the appetizer.  It was very good!  For the entree we shared the Jerk Chicken and Paella.  Both were to die for!!  Love love this place.  We will definitely make a trip back to Pittsburgh to eat at this creative restaurant.
Solid food and friendly, responsive bar staff. Can't wait to go back to try the burger! Glad to have it in my neighborhood.
Fish tacos are consistently delicious! I get them every time (or convince my husband to, so I can have a bite). Still love this place!

I got the fish tacos and white wine sangria. Both were very tasty. My dinner mates got the Cuban sandwich and paella. Everyone enjoyed their food. Nice atmosphere, good food, pretty good service- I'd recommend giving it a try. 
They do seem a little obsessed with having a reservation (even if tables are empty), so I would get a reservation first, just to make sure you don't get turned away.

Love the fish tacos here. They give you 3 tacos in a corn tortilla filled with crispy fish and cabbage slaw, avocado, and cilantro. The tortillas are apparently Reyna's tortillas which is the taco stand down the street which means they're freshly made corn tortillas. The tacos are a bit on the pricey end for the size of the tacos. $17 for three fish tacos.

The burger is probably worth more the price of $12. It's topped with all my favorite condiments: pickles, sunnyside up egg, avocado, tomato, and bacon. Also comes with Kaya chips which seems to be a mixture of potato chips and plantain chips.

My only complaint is the way they handle seating and reservations. It's pretty hard to come here without a reservation. Even if the restaurant is empty you might not be able to get in without a reservation.

They did accommodate us this one time when we had an extra person than what we originally said when we made a reservation. They seated us at a larger table but told us we had to finish within an hour or so. That was enough time and it was nice of them to allow us to switch tables rather than turn us away.

UPDATE May 2, 2018: Shout out to the grilled salmon with ramp chimmichurri!!i started with the deviled eggs and ramps with ramp chips. They were good, but the rampiness was weak. Not so with the salmon which also came with grilled asparagus and jicama. Both the eggs and salmon came with micro greens! So freaking good!!

UPDATE: Tonight, I came for dinner and had the Manchengo and Avacado Deviled Eggs, Caribbean Jerk Pork and Plantain Nachos, and Grilled flank steak. Another delicious and healthy dish. The flank steak was cooked to a perfect medium rare (note that I wasn't asked how I wanted it cooked). Peppers, mushrooms, avocados, cilantro, and a corn salsa. The salsa was quite vinegary, but I am into fermented foods and I am wondering if the salsa was fermented...That would make it even healthier. If it is not fermented, they need to work on their salsa recipe. 

Last comment: they have my most favorite beer Dechutes Fresh Squeezed on tap along with some good local craft brews.

By far the most interesting and flavorful food I found in Pittsburgh! I just loved Kaya, and went there at least three times while I was there visiting. 

I could always count on delicious vegetarian meals, like the spectacular risotto with a fried egg on top, the green Jamaican curry, and the egg and avocado torta. The appetizers were also top notch, especially the lentil and corn beignets (don't try to tackle these on your own, though -- there's more than enough to share with about 4 people) and the tofu cracklins. 

The service was always great and the servers were genuinely excited about the food being served -- and were happy to share their favorites, or steer you away from a choice that may not be quite as good. 

The meat-eaters who I dined with were incredibly impressed with the double cut pork chop, and the fish tacos (a friend, also from California, said they were the best she'd ever tasted). 

The atmosphere is funky, and the prices are very reasonable, too. Definitely worth a visit!

I went with a group of 6 friends for Sunday Brunch/Lunch. We were lucky to get a reservation a day earlier. The place usually gets booked for holidays for brunch. I was really looking forward to try the Island cuisine. The ambiance and service was pleasant and the appetizers were great. The cilantro- lime and cilantro cream sauce were unique and delicious. The Jamaican jerk wings were finger licking good, nice crispy skin with perfect spice-cover and juicy flesh with cilantro-cream sauce. The house-chips, black bean dip and mango salsa were great too. We ordered a plate of lentil-corn beignets too, after looking at the Yelp photographs , however was disappointed by the taste. The food went downhill from there. We ordered fish tacos and Huevos Rancheros. Two friends ordered the steal entree and shrimp omelette, which weren't all that amazing. I think the food severely lacked salt which is essential to bring out the real flavor in every dish. The Rancheros dish was too dry and bland and I couldn't finish mine, even after asking for extra sauce. One friend jokingly suggested that the appetizer menu looked so interesting, that we should just order all of them and make that our lunch. I wish we did that.
Delicious food and drinks! Our server was friendly and suggested some good items for us to try. We will come back to visit!

Five Stars - Beer selection on draft!!!! Oh my, probably one of the best in the Burgh for american craft brews on draft.

Three Stars - Food.  I assumed because they do a vegetarian price-fixe at times they would have good vegetarian eats, but they were strikingly mediocre.  Maybe I'm just not into Caribbean, but the bland, soggy pile laid before me doused in coconut milk just didn't cut it.  I'm sure this is a more exciting restaurant for the meat eaters among us.

Try the Kaya burger. They know how to cook a rarer  burger. The happy hr was pretty good this was the first time we went for that and good selection on IPA's on tap. The bread pudding is really large. The Chips(lots of spices) are good but I like the Fry s

It's alright.

The food has always been hit or miss for me. Some nights I'll get a delicious spread that I eat until I think my pants aren't going to button the next day and other nights I'll get somewhat 'okay' food. I've had mixed drinks before and they're strong- like no mixer strong. Which is fine if you're wanting to get wrecked but not fine if you plan on drinking it with your meal. 

The service varies according to what waiter you get. I've had some great service there but I've also had to literally chase down a waiter before in order to even get our order taken. They are pretty quick with getting food out and are on time with reservations, which is nice. 

The Kaya burger is delicious, but be prepared to eat it with a fork and knife. It's soggy as all get out but it's a delicious kind of soggy.
Excellent food and drinks. We just at off the tapas menu and they were able to accommodate our picky teens.

I saw this cute restaurant while I was walking this morning and decided to come in for dinner. The atmosphere is cute and the outdoor seating was very nice. The wait staff was pretty slow and kind of annoying. The food was good, not great. We got the spicy tuna poke and the pineapple seafood paella which were both just okay. Might be a little over priced for the portions.
Great!! Try the Vege burger for lunch!! Nice plated meal with a nice salad on the side. Good drinks and good fun.....Esp on a nice Saturday around the strip.

Planned on lunch there after reading the great reviews.  We started with the black bean dip.  When I noticed it was microwaved, we quickly paid our tab and went elsewhere to eat.  This is a neat little place with a cool Jamaican atmosphere, but the really have to lose the microwave.  I can make microwave dinners at home.

Happy Hours rock in general, but I have to admit I was impressed by Kaya's HH...1/2 off drinks - AWESOME!!! 

A friend I went there last week and we got the black bean dip (delish) and then I ordered the Jamaican jerk wings which I really enjoy with their cilantro cream sauce which is delectable. She got the fish tacos which I had a bite out of and they were sooooo good! 

We also got the BBQ Tofu thingy and have to admit - NOT a huge fan. There was little flavor to them and they had a cinnamony taste which was weird. Maybe I was expecting the Tofu that they have at Mad Mex as an appetizer (I think it's Asian inspired) which is really really good. 

So although I wasn't blown away by all the food, the fact that we were getting 1/2 off drinks and 90% of the food was very tasty - I think I'll check this place out more often!

Kaya is a Big Burrito joint and aims to hit the Caribbean in both atmosphere and flavor profile. I would say it succeeds moderately well in both departments. 

We had a number of dishes and drinks so I think we got a decent cross section of their offering. 

We both started with the Pisco Sour (we can't say no to egg white froth!) and gave the jerk wings and the curried cauliflower a shot as apps. 

The wings were spicy in a good way, but not spectacular. In fact, they tasted like regular old wings with jerk sauce poured over them. They were, however, plated on a creamy herb sauce that was quite excellent. 

The cauliflower was good, and had an interesting sauce and pistachios that actually gave it a new angle. 

The main dishes were oxtail (from the Trinidad special menu) as well as the famous rainbow salad with flank steak. 

Although the oxtail was very good, the portion size was tiny and not commensurate with the $15 price tag. 

The salad, however, was something to write home about! Hot damn, that was the best salad "as-a-meal" I've ever had! It was colorful with a dozen different ingredients, well dressed and perfectly cooked flank steak chunks. I would honestly go back for this salad alone. 

We sat at the bar, and service was decent, despite the busy night. All in all a good experience!

We were disappointed here. It was Sunday brunch, so perhaps this is not representative of the other items on the menu. I had the crab omelet ($10) and it was okay, but the crab didn't taste completely fresh. I dunno, maybe it is a Pittsburgh thing.  The strong mustard (infused with horseradish?) was a good addition to the flavor however. My dining companion had the curry vegetables ($10) and she was less than enthused. The best part was the appetizer of Kaya chips and Caribbean salsa ($7). Service was so-so. Our waitress seemed indifferent.

Food Quality/Taste = 2 Stars
Portion Size Given Price = 3 Stars
Price = 3 Stars
Service = 2 Stars
Experience with Staff = 2 Stars
Decor = 3 Stars
Clean (yes/no) = yes

Visited Kaya for the first time yesterday with a friend who loves the place.  It was around 3:30 and basically empty with the exception of a couple sitting at the bar, so we decided we'd also just take our place there.  The menu is small (1 page), but theres a lot of variety to choose from.  Reluctantly, I ordered the Kaya burger (I'm not really a burger fan and DEFINITELY not a bacon fan) because my friend gave me a couple of her faves and the burger was right on top, so I took her advice and went with that, cooked Med Well, with a side of sweet potato fries, and let me tell you, i ate every. last. bite.  it was that good.  So kudos to the cooks in the kitchen for making this hater of red meat and bacon clean her plate with no regrets!

We also ordered a pitcher of white sangria, which was OK.. I mean, we finished it so it wasn't bad, but I've had better (which is the only reason I gave this place 4 stars instead of 5.. but I've been told that the other drinks are amazing so maybe there will be a review update in my future). 

All in all, I really liked Kaya.  The theme and the decor was cool I thought, and the service was good.  Not fabulous, not horrible.. just your basic good service, and thats ok with me.  I was with a friend and enjoying stuffing my face with everything that I would normally never touch, so I wasn't looking for a chatty bartender anyway. Thumbs up, Kaya!

Mmm mmm good paella! So tasty. Highly recommend. 

Red sangria? Yes! 

Service? Really good. 

I've been hitting this place for the last three years and never have I been disappointed.

While I agree this place isn't an authentic Caribbean spot I think they do a good job of incorporating A Caribbean flare to the dishes. 

I got the flank steak and oxtail which came served over a plantain and squash hash. It was great! So flavorful and tender. The oxtail meat was shredded in with the hash. If you've ever had oxtails you know how difficult they can be.

My fianc ordered the fried chicken sandwich. It was good but wasn't that great. He did swap things around so it could of been amazing the original way. 

Will definitely visit again!

Went crazy here a few nights ago and ordered about eight dishes. The tuna, calamari, Nachos, chicken wings were fantastic. The burger is always the best. Ceviche was a great addition as well as the fish tacos. Flank steak was really tasty but a little tough. Otherwise, perfect meal.

I've been here many times and have never had a bad meal.  Stopped in for dinner recently on a Monday night with friends and we went crazy on the appetizers menu: tuna poke, bean dip, jerk wings, Tennessee-style drumsticks, conch fritters, green lentil and corn beignets. Top that off with some of the tastiest craft cocktails you can find and you'll be in store for an amazing dinner.

Easily the best culinary experience I had while visiting Pittsburgh. My boyfriend ordered the roasted chicken, which was succulent and well accompanied. I opted for the Cuban sandwich since I'm a junkie for the things... It was one of better renditions I've had outside of Miami.

Loved my fish tacos. Outside seating was perfect on a nice day. Only gripe was that my date's fish sandwich was very dry, especially with the dry bun used. 

Oh, bean dip and chips were awesome too.

Kaya was great for Sunday brunch and during happy hour (rated separate days).

Chiliquiles and Chantralle/manchego cheese omelet were really good. Started off with Kaya chips and mango salsa with blood orange mimosas. Finished with a Belgian waffle coffee drink that tasted like a yummy alcoholic maple syrup drink. The service was outstanding. Friendly relaxed atmosphere.  Easy like a Sunday morning with Calypso and Raggae music playing in the background. Mexican and southwestern decor. Pretty cool place.  

 For happy hour --good beer and tequila selection. Fun atmosphere. Vegan and vegetarian friendly.

Definitely will return!

Walked in without a reservation and was politely declined seating but was given the opportunity to find bar seats, if available. Luckily, we were able to convince our friendly neighbors to scoot over a few spaces such that my family of 4 could fit.

We started off with the Kaya juice which is a combination of 4 fruit juices (mango, guava, pineapple, and grapefruit - I think). Drink wasn't too sweet and was very refreshing on such a humid night.

For appetizers, we opted for the Yucatan hot bean dip and the cheese/corn fritters. The fritters were just okay...presented more like cheese sticks than fritters. The chipotle sauce that accompanied them though was good. As for the bean dip - order this! The bean dip is hot and gooey from the melted cheese served with a hearty side of house made chips. Some pieces were definitely overdone, but most were seasoned well and not too well done. Actually, it was a pretty divine bite when you combined the bean dip and the chipotle sauce...yum!

For entrees, we ordered from the more 'casual' menu but I was surprised at the portion sizes! 

My fish tacos were huge! The tacos featured creamy guac, approximately 2 filets of crispy fish per tacos, and a hearty topping of slaw. The slaw was just okay in my opinion...had a hint of ginger which didn't pair especially well with cilantro and limes. Mom opted for the flank steak sandwich. GET. THIS. The steak was sooo tender and had the right balance of flavors. The waffle fries were a bit too salty though. Brother opted for the pulled pork quesadilla but found it to be too pork heavy and severely lacking in cheese or other toppings. His sweet potato fries were on point though. Dad ordered the regular cubano and enjoyed it.

Kaya is on my "Top 5" list in Pittsburgh for sure.  Anything I have ever had here has been wonderful.  My absolute favorite thing here is the fried tofu plate that they have on fried chicken nights now--it's hard to make something like tofu taste this amazing!  (And probably totally unhealthy as well).  

I also like the kaya veggie burger, the black bean dip, any fish I've ever eaten here, and don't even get me started on the cocktail menu...it's SO hard to decide!  Even if you don't think you like Caribbean food or spicy things, give it a shot.  There's something for everyone and I will come back until I've tried everything, and probably more times after that!  It's wonderful!!

I ate here for brunch this past weekend with my girlfriend and her parents for Father's Day.  We had made reservations earlier in the week for when Kaya opened and I am glad that we did as the restaurant seemed to fill up quickly shortly after we arrived.

We decided to start off our brunch by splitting the conch fritters.  There were seven conch balls that were served on top of a tropical tarter sauce that contained capers.  The conch was nice and crispy and paired well with the slightly salty tarter sauce.  For my entree I decided upon the slow roasted pork benedict.  After a long wait of about 70 minutes after being seated, it finally arrived.  Even though I generally do not like cornbread, I enjoyed the play on Eggs Benedict by using the cornbread as the English muffin and pork instead of the ham.  It tasted wonderful as well with the pork being tender and juicy while the lime hollandaise sauce had a good flavor to it.  The sides were good to as they made a sweet and savory mixture with the hash browns mixed in with pineapple chunks.  Several times during the wait for our entrees the waitress apologized to us and even took the step of notifying the manager that our food took a long time, without us saying a word about it. After the meal the manager came over to us and apologized herself and comped two of the meals, once again without us having said anything.  From that I would have to say that they have some pretty good customer service.

The bottom line for me is that I have been here many times before and will be headed back again.  Kaya has both interesting and tasty dishes that you will not find anywhere else in the city and I was more than impressed with their customer service this past visit.

After hearing some really good things about Kaya, my wife decided to take me here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon. Several people have raved to me about their chicken and waffles and I wanted the chance to indulge!  

My wife ended up ordering the chicken and waffles, promising me a few bites so that I was able to order the tropical paella.  Last year I was first introduced to paella and loved it.  Needless to say, Kaya's paella was excellent. The scallops, mussels, and shrimp were blended beautifully with chicken and chorizo with not one element overtaking the dish.  I also thoroughly enjoyed the sampling of chicken and waffles I had from my wife's plate. For some reason, fried chicken always taste so much better with waffles and maple syrup! We ended up ordering some coffee and tea to go with our meals.  A little pricey for each, but we both needed a nice pickup after our filling meal.

Kaya definitely lived up to my expectations.  I really enjoyed our brunch here and was pleased to see the prices on the menu were reasonable for a nicer brunch place with good food. I saw a few things on the men that I would like to come back to try, especially the rainbow salad. Kaya is a solid choice for taste and price and I imagine this will be one of my default go to places in the strip when I'm in the area.

I have not actually been in the restaurant itself, but have ordered delivery from them numerous of evenings! The Chicken Sandwich with Waffle Fries is my go-to order, but I have also enjoyed the Shanghai Ribs, Queso, their Burger, and the Sweet Potato Fries. All were 5 stars!

This review is for catering: I've ordered from Big Burrito catering a few times. The Kaya option is, without a doubt, my favorite. Robin has been my contact and does a fantastic job helping me stay on budget, while still providing me such great food options!

This most recent time, I ordered food for 50 and it was delivered.. (by Robin's husband, he introduced himself after I was raving about Robin. We then struck up a convo about how I think Bill Fuller must be a cool human after listening to him on WYEP. Hey Bill - If you read this, I need to know if you'll adopt me around holidays!)

Okay, back on topic. I ordered a sandwich, salad and paella combo. The order arrived on time and was set up fabulously. I love that I can always count on those print-out cards to label the food. With events, I am always being asked what ingredients are in the food, so it's great to defer to the cards. Both the veggie cuban and the chicken sandwiches are big hits. Ended up having a large amount of the paella left over, mostly due to the amount included. 

If you're looking for unique catering options, I would highly suggest Kaya. The menu is easy to customize and able to accommodate vegetarians. 

One last thing: a tip on tipping.. Ask to add it to the invoice, otherwise it will be too late to add on once delivered!

Kaya is a staple for Pittsburgh, so if you're visiting, and want some great South American/Caribbean style food Kaya is a must.

Located in Pittsburgh's Strip District neighborhood Kaya has an eclectic and festive atmosphere.  The staff are friendly and attentive and the menu should make everyone happy.

Happy hour is amazing - HALF OFF ALL DRINKS.  Sorry, I didn't mean to yell, but this is exciting information.  And they have awesome mojitos and margaritas.  

On my most recent visit I had the tempura avocado Bahn Mi tacos.  I loved the carrot and radish garnish with the cilantro but this was just a little too spicy for me with the addition of the jalapenos.  I had to take the jalapenos off and then I enjoyed them much more.  You're given three very nice portions (tacos).  

I also had the Kaya chips with mango salsa.  That salsa is amazing!

Kaya, I'll be back (likely during happy hour).

Kaya's is a great little gem found in the heart of the strip District. They have some amazing Caribbean drinks, including a dark and stormy which I haven't had since I was in Bermuda. Delicious!! The appetizers are to die for, and their fish tacos are exquisite. I highly recommend popping into this place for a drink or a bite to eat

Though my husband and I enjoyed our first experience at Kaya (a Friday night dinner), our recent Sunday brunch experience made me revisit my 4 star review. 

Four words for you... Fried Chicken and Waffle. For only $13, you can partake of one of the best brunch dishes of all time. The menu describes this item so normally, but this isn't a normal dish. The waffle is good but the chicken packs a spicy punch while the maple syrup is extra sweet to balance that sassy Caribbean flavor. It's an absolutely incredible experience, and we'll definitely be back to enjoy it again.
Great food! Very different from other restaurants in Pittsburgh. Intimate atmosphere yet casual. Service is great as well. Smaller restaurant but very spacious with their seating.

This is my boyfriend and I first time visit yet kaya's associate is very nice and helpful. We've tried fish taco(super huge-normally you will get three huge tacos in one dishes yet you will get four once you mention you want to split it into two (like my boyfriend and I did). If you in favor of sore flavor you will like it! Also, parking is quite convenient in front of kaya.

I was in Pittsburgh for the weekend, and me and my wife were looking for a good place to grab a late lunch in the strip district.  A few places we tried to go to were closed (which I thought was odd for a Sunday when both the Pirates and Steelers had home games), so we ended up going to Kaya based on the good reviews onlined.

We got there at around 3:00, and I was upset when I found out that I couldn't order some of the dishes I saw on the online menu, because they don't start serving dinner until 4:00.  So I ended up "settling" for the Cuban sandwich.  It turned out to be one of the best sandwiches I've ever had in my life.  My wife had a chorizo and eggs breakfast dish that she loved also.

So the food was amazing, the place has nice decor, good music at an appropriate (not too loud volume), and the Pirates game on the TV.  Next time in Pittsburgh I'd like to go back and try some of the things I didn't get the chance to order off of the dinner menu.

Oh, and the food was very reasonably priced.  $10 for an amazing sandwich, waffle fries and some pickles!
Nice atmosphere, super nice wait staff.....The crab sandwich and salad was delicious and so are the sweet potatoe fries.  Plus they have an excellent Boulder cold hop IPA on tap...

Actually, 4.5.

We had brunch on Sunday. Kaya has a fantastic menu that mixes a number of cultures, but still seems fantastically simple. It's a great space, wonderful service, and very attentive across the board. Amongst the four the us we had three benedicts (two with soy sausage, one with smoked salmon), and the monstrous mushroom and cheese omelet. Top marks across the board. They even added a nice side plate of slice avocado on request. Great drinks, great coffee, great place.

I've always enjoyed dining at Kaya. Most recently, I went for dinner with two of my close friends. We had and I suggest making a reservation, even if you're planning on dining during the week. It was quite busy for a Thursday at 7pm. 

Upon arrival, we were promptly seated toward the back of the restaurant. Our sever, Autumn, greeted us and gave us ample time to review the drink and food menu.

In addition to a fun selection of cocktails, they also have a large wine menu. We each ordered a glass of wine ($10).

We decided to order an appetizer and chose the calamari. I always like calamari, but I always think it tastes the same. Which leads me to ask, why do I order it? Anyway, instead of a traditional marinara on the side, they served theirs with a yummy, green sauce. Slightly spicy tangy, but delicious. The calamari wasn't super greasy (a plus).

For our entrees, I ordered the fish tacos (grilled, not crispy) ($18), and the other two ordered the fried chicken special ($18) and a fancy burger (can't remember exactly what made it so special). The tacos, something I've had many times before are just wonderful. The kitchen doesn't skimp here, packing each with a nice portion of fish, coleslaw and dressing. The fried chicken platter looked amazing. Keep in mind that they only serve the fried chicken on Thursday nights (perhaps that's why it was so busy?). My friend noted that the chicken was super delicious (it looked it!).

We didn't stick around for dessert because we were so full.

All in all, a really great night at a fun restaurant in Pittsburgh's Strip District.

Got to have Kaya now! Cozy atmosphere. Creative dishes. Nice little selection of "tropas" to snack on. My friend and I split tofu lettuce wraps, tropical guacamole with Kaya chips, Brussels sprouts and cauliflower and lentil corn beignets. All of those selections were very delicious and obviously vegetarian friendly (lots of meat though for those who are into that). The lettuce wraps were particularly fantastic. Sangria was tasty but weak. Overall, this restaurant is recommended! I will come back if I'm back in town. PS - Pittsburgh is kind of cool. Cooler than expected.

If this restaurant were a boat, they'd have forgotten to put a "k" on the end of their name.  Happily, however, this restaurant is not a boat.  It's a restaurant.  (I may now refer to myself as Captain Obvious in the third person for the rest of this review.)

Captain Obvious went to lunch at Kaya.  She ordered the following menu items: 1.  A glass of red sangria, 2. a cup of gazpacho verde 3. a small isabeleta(?) and monchego grilled sandwich with lime oil, arugula and some other item in there of which Captain Obvious does not recall the name.  The sandwich came with two sides.  Captain Obvious chose the spicy slaw and petite salad. 

Considering that an appetizer and meal generally is generally a overzealous amount of food, I... I mean Captain Obvious... was very please with the portion sizes.  They were mid-sized, reasonably small, yet still big (go figure that out) portions of delicious.  The sandwich and gazpacho were particularly delish.  Delish dish! (Say that 10 times fast). The side salads were nice, but they were side salads aka somewhat boring. The Sangria... well perhaps they should rename it Saintgria, because it was heavenly.  Actually, it might have been a touch too sweet, but I liked saying that.  It was good in any case.

One downside was the the service was kinda slow... It took a long time for the waitress to get us our drinks and apps (which considering that they were just soup should have been easy to maneuver). The entrees came perhaps a bit to quick.  Time is always of the essence, so that could be worked on.  

In addition, the chairs... ugh... who designed those?  Clearly, they never sat in them, because they weren't great for posture or comfort and, let's face it, chairs should meet one of those two basic needs at very least. Let this be a lesson to you all:  Sit in every chair you design before finalizing plans.  (Captain Obvious design chairs ALLLL the time - don't you?) 

In all though, Captain Obvious did like the place and mmm to the food.
Excellent happy hour! 1/2 price delicious cocktails. Highly recommend the basil-grapefruit marg.

What a bummer. Totally overpriced and overcooked fish. Per the servers suggestion, I got the porgy fish, which was completely overcooked and dry. Pretty disappointing.

Mojito was decent and outdoor seating was nice. Service was not overwhelmingly friendly, but it was fine.

Wow not sure where to begin here! I came here last week during Kayafest and had an amazing meal! I've past Kaya so many times and now i regret all that time i never tried it! We made a reservation to avoid the wait. I'm pescatarian so when I looked at the menu I was surprised by how MANY options they had for me to choose from. I got the fried avocado bahn mi tacos, my husband got the Chile rellenos, my sister got the rainbow salad and her bf got the fried chicken wings. We all LOVED our food. The tacos were surprisingly large portions and i was stuffed but i still managed to shovel in those last 2 bites. Shout out to Brian who gave great recommendations and was super nice! Do not skip out on this place!

I have now been to Kaya twice, once for dinner and once for brunch and both occasions the food has been lackluster at best. 

Kaya is attempting to pull off a high concept fusion style restaurant, blending Caribbean, South American, Pacific and Mexican cuisine into an appetizing blend of food. To be perfectly honest I am skeptical of fusion places due to the high rate of failures in execution. In many cases you have a young hot-shot chef who wants to be known as a bold flavor innovator, blending cuisines that he has never mastered to achieve usually poor to mediocre results. The dishes in many cases have only a vague similarity to the original and if it would be beneficial if the chef would stick to concentrating on the basics instead of cooking up bizarre fusion dishes.

Some examples would be the Jamaican Jerk Chicken Wings - which tasted nothing like Jerk seasoning should (loaded with allspice, heat of the scotch bonnet pepper, cinnamon, cloves, etc. Instead it looked like we had a dab of commercially bought jerk seasoning tossed on the wings after cooking. The wings themselves were cooked nicely, big and juicy but still had some pin feathers attached that were not removed, attention to details such as this is mandatory. 

For brunch I tried the eggs benedict with smoked salmon, the eggs were poached hard, again another detail that is unacceptable and sloppy. The salmon was cheap, the cornbread it was served on was good and made for an interesting combination but the addition of smoked paprika on top was okay, but nothing exciting. 

I could go on and on, but you see the problems.

2.5 Stars because the place is interesting for Pittsburgh but for those of us who have traveled and eaten in the Caribbean, South America and Mexico, the food comes off as dull copies of vibrant originals.

I received a certificate for up to $30 off an entree for any of the Big Burrito restaurants for my birthday (you can sign up for this on their website). I decided to try out Kaya for my birthday dinner. I selected the seared ahi tuna and it was excellent. The meal paired a lot of different items that hit different taste buds. There was a rice that was a little spicy and tasted great with some sort of green (I think arugula) that had a tart flavor. The tuna was perfectly seared in my opinion. The staff was also very friendly, especially the woman that seated us. The only complaint that I would have is that the restaurant was on the smaller side. My friend and I unwillingly listened to the party next to us debate on who had how many rum runners so they could split their check.

We had exceptional service here last night. The food was also excellent. I split guacamole with a friend. The guacamole was so good. The tropical aspect with the mango and like made it so Delicious. The chips that came with it were seasoned and so tasty also! My main dish was the flank steak cemita with waffle fries. The waffle fries were so delicious. Really crisp, could tell they made them on the spot and were not frozen & heated up. The flank steak cemita was delicious. I usually don't eat steak, and the steak was cooked amazingly. It wasn't too medium or well done, and it had a lot of flavor. They put a good layer of lettuce and tomato. I hate places that skimp! Finally I got a angry orchard cider. They poured it into a cute little glass. Really exceptional service, beautiful decor, and great food. Makes the pricier tag worth it. My food cost $25 with tax
I actually love this place for the special drinks like Graduate and the Caribbean Jerk wings. They are awesome, they tend to look underdone inside a bit pinker than they should but they are great.

Kaya is another offering from Big Burrito and if you're familiar with their other restaurants (especially Mad Mex), you'll know what to expect from the vibe. It's a pretty dark space, heavily style with an island flair...both in decor and menu. The menu is pretty small, but all of the items that I've tried have been pretty good, and the service has always been really good, whether sitting inside or outside.

We absolutely love their black bean dip, but fair warning: it's pretty spicy if you're not good with heat. The burger is good, as well as the cuban sandwich, but my go-to is probably the fish tacos. I tend to think they overdo it on the cream sauce, but otherwise, they're excellent. The red sangria is also delicious! I wouldn't say the food will blow you away, but I doubt you'll be disappointed, either.

It's warm vibe and good service means it's good for both casual meals and for a nice date night spot. The strip district can be insane at times, so while you may have luck grabbing a table or seats at the bar on a whim, I'd advice making a reservation to save yourself a wait. Enjoy!

Amazing way to spend a Sunday. I visited Kaya for brunch, which is only offered on Sunday, and was pleasantly impressed. From the moment we walked in the door, we were thoroughly taken care of. The hostess, whose name I didn't catch, was a wonderful woman who offered us a table even though they had a reservation coming in at 2. 

We opted for the mojito and grapefruit-basil margaritas instead of traditional brunch cocktails and they were fantastic. The tropical guac (order the homemade kaya chips to substitute the tortilla chips) was awesome, I really wanted to take it home with me. We chose the chicken and waffles (it came with a spicy Tabasco butter which added an extra layer of flavor) and the huevos rancheros. I was super excited that the huevos rancheros came with ~more~ of the tropical guac, but it was all in all a fantastic dish. The bacon was peppery and delicious, albeit I wish it was a bit crispier, but it was a great juxtaposition to the sweetness of the grilled pineapple.

I'll have to come back and see what Kaya has to offer besides an awesome brunch, but if brunch is what you're in the market for, definitely come check it out next time you are doing your Sunday shopping in the Strip.
Delicious food! I've been there multiple times and keep coming back. Jerk wings are hands down the best thing on the menu. The place is small so make reservations.
The brought us the wrong but easily fixed it. Food came quickly and was interesting. The pork sandwich was a little dry but we will definitely be back.

Despite Kaya already being well-reviewed, I still think it's underrated.  In addition to executing well on dishes within its wheelhouse, Kaya manages to far exceed expectations on other fronts as well.  For example, the burger here is easily in the Top 10 I've had in Pittsburgh, and they cooked it better than even many well-known burger places (beating comparable burgers I've ordered at BRGR, Union Grill and Tessaro's).  I also wouldn't overlook Kaya as a stellar brunch option; their menu offers plenty of variety, great flavors, and combinations ranging from classic to inventive.  Not only is Kaya a very good restaurant, it's stunningly well-rounded as well.

My friend and I were in town for a Pens game, and stumbled upon Kaya while exploring the Strip District. Every other brunch spot we saw was packed with a line going out the door. No thanks on the wait, we were starving!

We were seated immediately, and brought drinks. The bloody marys were a little spicy, but the waiter had warned us (and thoughtfully gave us a glass of tomato juice to cut them). We ordered sweet potato fries as an appetizer, and they were honestly some of the best I've ever had. The chipotle mayo dip for the fries was really good too.

We each had a benedict for our entree, I had the pulled pork one and my friend had the smoked salmon. I liked their take on the benedict, with corn bread as the base, and the slightly sweet/spicy hollandaise. Our benedicts came with grilled pineapple and potatoes. 

Overall, I was very happy with our experience at Kaya. The one ding I would give it is because the service was slow, but the food was great. If I'm ever back in Pittsburgh, I would visit this restaurant again.

I had a made a reservation for saturday evening, however found that the Bar was fine and received service there. The Bar tender was very nice and attentive, even being as busy as he was. We started with the Kaya chips with mango salsa. The chips were very good, however some were a little too burnt. The salsa was amazing though, and I loved the kick that the chips had to them! I was in a Kaya kind of mood, so I also got the Kaya burger, med well, with sweet potato fries and this cayenne dipping sauce (one of many sauces they offer). The burger was perfect with just enough pink, and the avocado and egg was the perfect blend. The sweet potato fries were awesome, hard to mess that up.

Sooo that was a pretty fantastic sandwich...

Let me explain the pork and banana sandwich for you from bun to bun:
Slice: fluffy baguette
red onion
cilantro mayo
lime
slow cooked pulled pork
sliced plantains
Slice: fluffy baguette
**if you're one who enjoys the dynamic duo of savory and sweet - this dandy is for you!

According to our Pittsburgh hostess with the mostess, Rachel C, we HAD to order the sweet potato fries as they were some of the best in the city - and, she added, that they paired nicely with an order of the cilantro mayo. True and true! From the sidewalk looking in this place is extremely unsuspecting - I didn't even realize there was anything there until she swung the door open. Inside sits a Caribbean oasis tucked away in the heart of the Strip District. Warm lighting with a long bar that boasts tiki-style bar chairs and colorful walls. By ordering the "Todo en Uno" portion size I was able to have a smaller version of the sandwich with a side. 

Rachel informed our crew that Kaya is a great spot for Happy Hours and that in her downtown working days she was a regular;) Next time, Rachel, - you + me + Kaya.

I reserve the 5 star glory for places that truly rock my foodie world. Everything about my Sunday brunch experience had my tastebuds begging for more! 

My friend and I stopped in after shopping for groceries  in the Strip. We were seated immediately in a spot with plenty of room to place our grocery bags next to us. Our waitress was friendly & gave excellent recommendations for drinks. We started with a bloody mary and grapefruit margarita. I got the horseradish infused vodka in my first bloody mary and the old bay infused vodka in my second. Both were the perfect kick but the horseradish had a stronger flavor. Our app was the mango pineapple gaucemole. The mango overpowered the pineapple but not the avocado! I would order that dip again. I stuck with Bloody marys throughout our meal and my friend switched to a mojito. It was crisp, fresh and well blended. 
For our entrees, I got the Jamaican veggie curry and my friend got the flank steak burger with arugula and truffle aioli and a side salad. Wow! Both dishes were incredible!!! The citrus that pulled through my curry was a delightful surprise and the portion was huge. It was served with saffron rice and I had to leave most of the rice behind. My friend demolished the burger in record time. The aioli was the perfect compliment. I am not a burger fan but one bite of her dish, I saw the appeal. 
The attentive service, excellent food and drinks screamed 5 star. I am excited for my next trip back to further explore the menu and libation creations!

A takeout visit for te Cuban Sandwich, Jerked pork and Plantain nachos. Overall, the Cuban sandwich was absolutely phenomenal! However, the plantain nachos tasted as though they accidentally dropped their entire spice rack into the jerked pork.

Cuban sandwich: a sumptuous mix of different kinds of well-seasoned meats melded together with creamy cheese and savory aioli. Although the sandwich was a bit heavy, it was incredibly delicious, and I look forward to tasting other sandwiches they have to offer.

Jerked pork and plantain chips: the plantain chips by themselves were crispy, well-salted and delicious. However, as I mentioned above, my taste buds felt that they were on a roller coaster ride of different spices, some of which may have gone well, but others that made me wonder "I think something happened in the kitchen, and it involves someone experimenting with every spice he has in his spice rack". I personally would not recommend this dish.

Overall, the receptionist was welcoming, servers were kind and patient with our orders, and wait for take-out was not long at all.

The Cuban was a solid 4.5, the Plantain nachos a 1.5, service 4, ambiance 4.

My boyfriend and I went there for his birthday, and we both absolutely loved it. The server was extremely helpful and friendly. My boyfriend ordered the fish tacos, and he said they were some of the best he's ever had. We both loved their calamari, as well. Oh, and their specialty cocktails were excellent.

I went with a party of five, and it was the first time for all of us.  We got the Philippine special.  They gave us a lot of food, and it was good.  the chicken adobe was a little salty, but the food was quite good.  The waiter and chef were friendly.  The waiter did a good job.  It was pricey.  35 dollars a person.  They did not put the price on the menu.  I believe they should, as sometimes you feel funny having to ask the cost.
Speaking of asking, our party of five consisted of two couples, and a single.  They gave us one check.  I do not understand why restaurants are not more thoughtful in this regard.  It is as if their attitude is "well, if they ask, we can split the checks, but if they don't ask, why should we make more work for us?"  All I know is that if I owned a restaurant, I am going to do all things big and small to make it as pleasurable an experience as possible.  Everything counts!
But the biggest thing was that the chef (congenial as he was) had an unkempt beard that was sort of dangling over our food.  I know how today's society is, but that is not right.  As of now, I am not going back.  But if they make two simple changes (automatically ask the party how they want the checks done and have any chefs shave a long beard (small beard is ok), I will go back.  One other positive.  I see the manager, or whoever it is, responds to some of these reviews in an attempt to right some wrongs..  I think that is the right idea.

Atmosphere, food, drinks are great. Not too many places I would give a 5 star but this is the exception. I've eaten here a few times and each time has been phenomenal. Coming from a vegetarian that says a lot. The rainbow salad is fantastic.

Since Big Burrito was kind enough to send me a gift card in the mail for mah birthday, my boyfriend insisted that we go out to dinner for my birthday...again....yes, this was my third birthday dinner in the period of one week.  Hey, you only turn 27 once!

I decided we should go on a Thursday, because that was Fried Chicken Night and I don't even need to say why that sounds insanely awesome.  I didn't even end up ordering the fried chicken, but I made my boyfriend get it so I could try it.  Birthday girl gets to make decision!  We didn't make reservations, just showed up around 7 pm or so.  They were pretty busy and we thought we'd have to wait awhile, but by the time we ordered drinks at the bar, our table was ready.

We both ordered delicious cocktails - one was a grapefruit-basil margarita, and I forgot what the other one was.  That's what I get for being a bad Yelper and not posting for a few weeks.  Since it wasn't quite 7 pm yet, our drinks were half off, making any cocktail suddenly an amazing bargain.  Definitely a good reason to come to Kaya early!  

Our server was friendly, and he recommend the barramundi in chile broth.  I sprung for it, since it was an expensive entree and I wanted to get my gift card's worth.  My boyfriend got the fried chicken, at my insistence.  Let me say that my barramundi was OUTSTANDING.  Way better than I expected.  Fresh, flavorful, and just marvelous all around.  Totally worth the money, but if you have a gift card then it's a don't-miss!  I was so happy that I didn't even really want to share my boyfriend's chicken, but I took a few bites.  It was incredibly crispy, which I loved, but honestly it wasn't as flavorful as I hoped.  More salt in the breading needed, perhaps?  Chicken was very juicy though - just didn't deliver a flavor punch.  It was served with a salsa of some sort, so perhaps that was meant to compensate, but I hoped for more kick.

I wouldn't get the chicken again, but I'd go back in a heartbeat for that barramundi and another half-price cocktail!  mmmmmm.

We came here based on the recommendation of a bartender on the other side of town, so we had high hopes. As much as I wanted to like to, I just couldn't.

The drinks were OK at best. The food, incredibly over priced, but not half bad. Our server on the other hand just sucked. With only 4 tables filled, it took 20 minutes to be greeted and get water. After an hour, we finally got some good. The table was positioned so that you could see into the kitchen. We saw our server standing over the food she was supposed to be boxing, eating something else. Completely gross. 

Additionally, saw several people in street clothes bring guests into the kitchen for a few minutes, then leave - seemed like employees bringing their girlfriends for a tour. 

The food and drinks were 2 stars at worse, but slow, rude service and grossness gives it 1.

We went to Kaya last night for dinner.  We were seated outside which was great!  Make reservations because it's definitely a really busy restaurant.  

We really did not enjoy the food.  We got the guacamole which comes in a really small bowl, with basic Tostitos chips, and ends up costing $11.  We ended up asking the waitress to give us more or at least fill the bowl up to the top.  She said these were their portion sizes, did go back to the restaurant and added maybe a spoonful more, and then said she'll have to charge us if we still wanted more.  I understand but probably a little more than half an avocado was used in that guacamole bowl. 

My husband got the jerk chicken wings.  He said it grew on him eventually but it wasn't spicy.  I believe the sauce that comes with it is cilantro aioli? which makes dipping the jerk chicken in it taste even more mild.  The sauce was pretty yummy.

I got the vegetarian Caribbean rainbow salad with tofu because the description sounds SO yummy.  It was not.  It tasted bland and there wasn't any dressing on it.  I typically don't add dressing to my salads -- a little olive oil and lemon goes a long way.  But this salad was just tasteless and it was the first time where I wished for dressing.

The drinks were yummy!  We both tried a cocktail and both were delicious.  I would go there for drinks and apps but not dinner.

Illuminated only by the track lighting hanging from the ceiling, the glow of a monitor, and spotlights placed upon the bar, this suave, darkly lit atmosphere screams classy dining with eclectic Caribbean dcor. A medium to small sized joint to enjoy dinner and start your Friday bar crawl. Most patrons here are dressed in casual to semi-formal or business attire. 

The environment is fairly loud. You have to practically yell to be heard by the person across the table, and people sitting next to each other still had trouble hearing each other. This was mainly the result of the music, although the words and language used in most of the songs were indistinguishable. However, the music was clearly a mix of genres, from hip hop and R'n'B to Reggae, from Latin American pop to soft rock from the 80s. Later, in the night, this music was quite upbeat and made everyone want to dance! This appears to be a calculated move, since when hip hop is played on busier nights, the fast music leads to quicker table turnover. 

I ordered the Kaya Juice, a delicious mock tail comprised of mango, guava, cranberry, and pineapple juices. The cranberry juice's bitterness and the muted sweetness of guava temper the overwhelmingly sugary pineapple and mango juices. The conch fritters appeared similar to a pakora, a deep fried and breaded vegetable appetizer featured Indian and Pakistani cuisines. Biting into it yielded a chewy, salty and quite savory taste, made deliciously tangy by lime squeezed on top of it. Underneath the fritters was a green habanero aioli, about as spicy as a teaspoon of Cholula. This was incredibly potent, with a delicious mix of savory ingredients reminiscent of Hispanic Caribbean, potentially Cuban, cuisine.

The entre was a monthly special, the Bake 'n' Shark burger, composed of lettuce, tomato, tamarind, cilantro, hot sauce, and fried bread. The taste was initially tangy, and slightly sweet from the sauce. Unfortunately, the shark part itself was quite underwhelming. Even though the shark patty was breaded and fried, the fish itself tasted extremely bland, like unseasoned tilapia. The mixture of cucumber, crunchy iceberg lettuce, leafy cilantro and other textures added interesting dimension to this otherwise tasteless dish. Its crunchy, possibly fried hamburger bun felt unusual, like an oily cracker. This and was probably the best part of the entire meal. Indeed, the conch fritters probably overshadowed the main course with their flavor and spice. Yet the shark burger's only selling point was its exotic nature. 

Overall, it was a great experience! Although I found my entre to be bland, I'm excited to come back and enjoy other plates when the next opportunity arises.

Another terrible experience at a big burrito restaurant. This is probably the 10th bad experience I've had at a big burrito restaurant. Usually it's Mad Mex, but this time it was Kaya. I walked in and asked for a table for two and a half. The hostess who didn't make eye contact with me, informed me there was nothing but outside seating available. It's funny because there was over half the room available inside. Her claims over reserved tables were unwarranted, there were plenty of tables open and weren't being seated for another 45 minutes. AVOID THIS DUMP.
Fun vibe! Tried the Caribbean rainbow salad and the Kaya burger. Well seasoned, lots of flavour. Would definitely go back to try different things!

I got the Kaya Burger, because I kept reading such good things about it. It is possibly the messiest burger I've ever received. Very, very wet. The bottom of the bun was deteriorated by the time I got it. I tried the fork and knife approach, but they serve it on wax paper, so now I have wax paper in my food. TIp: If you order the burger, get them to put it on a normal plate, and put the sauce or whater it is on the side.

Also, for some reason, the mixed drinks were not good at all. I got the "Tiki #7," which really tasted like frozen juice concentrate (just bitter sour and lots of acid. I sent it back and got a "Mojito" which was basically a mixer with mint leaves on top. Not great.

After many years of enjoying and recommending Kaya, I am reluctantly forced to downgrade it from 4.5 stars to  2.5. As uncharacteristic as it is for a Big Burrito Group establishment, I must sadly report that the  service and food quality have diminished to the point of  consistent disappointment.

I have to say I never really had Kaya on my list of places I wanted to try. It was on the list but it was very bottom of the huge list. A friend asked to go here one day for happy hour and I'm pretty glad she picked it. From the outside this place looks a lot bigger then it really is. I was expecting it to be much bigger.

All of the drinks we ordered were unique and had great flavor. I also decided to order some of the tofu lettuce wraps. I was also very impressed with those. They were similar to the tofu from Pan and Mad Mex. And I'm a sucker for some goof tofu. After this experience I'll definitely be bumping Kaya up on my list to try for an actual meal.
Whenever I'm in Pittsburgh, I come here. The food is always good. The service is up to par as well. Highly recommend this spot.

The drinks and atmosphere: awesome! Those plantain chips: amazing! I love the vibe of this place and they had some of the best sangria I have ever tasted, but came short when it comes to food. If I had even a slightly better meal, I would have bumped the rating up, but unfortunately it wasn't good at all. I went for lunch with co-workers and ordered the Green Vegetable Curry. It was seasoned oddly, and the rice was super salty. The sauce was not really there, leaving dried, weird seasoned vegetables in a heap. I tried working around it but it was such a big pile of food, it was unappetizing. Maybe it's just this dish that's not up to par? Everyone else really loved their food! I also see another review about the curry dish... I am definitely coming back here, hopefully for a better experience!

I had really high expectations for this place after hearing so much about it, so that may be part of why I'm only giving it 3 stars, but I really didn't think it was that amazing.  I went with a group of 15 where we had a reservation a few weeks in advance for such a large group.  After we made our reservation, my understanding is that they later asked us to move the time up from our original 7pm to 7:45 pm since that was a less busy time for them, which I found kind of odd since they should give priority to who called first.  Since they close at 10pm and dinner with that large of a group can take while, around 9:40 they started bringing checks out even though some people's desserts hadn't arrived yet, which I also found to be unusual and kind of annoying when they did push our time up 45 min.  

The service was just ok, but decent for such a large group.  When I sat down I had no drink menu (though did have a food menu) but there was one way on the other side of a very large table.  I asked the waiter for a drink menu and he said his hands were full but that there was already one on the table---ummm way down on the other end and people were using it.  He said he'd be back with one in a bit anyway, but when he came back he had no menu so I then had to eventually get it passed all the way down the table when he finally brings more.  They did have a very nice drink list, including an impressive draft selection that I was happy about.

As for the food, it was a little pricier than I was expecting for Caribbean food so I expected it to be amazing (most entrees in the upper $20's, and appetizers also expensive--chips and salsa was like $7/8!!).  I ordered the bbq tofu cracklings for an appetizer which was tasty but way too huge, and I normally really like generous portions--it filled up a HUGE plate and was bigger than my entree so I could not even eat half of it.  I would have much rather preferred a smaller appetizer for half the price.  It was tasty but there was a bit too much bbq sauce on it and it really was just fried not so crispy tofu, not sure why they called it cracklins--I was expecting something much crispier.  For my entree I ordered the flank steak and the presentation was beautiful and the fried egg on top was a nice touch.  I asked for it cooked medium and it came out exactly as I requested.  However, although it tasted quite good and flavorful, the steak was quite chewy, which was disappointing for something that looked so lovely.  I was expecting a higher quality of meat for the price ~$26.

The atmosphere and decor are very nice and the bar seems to be the centerpiece here although there's a decent amount of table seating.  I think I'd come back for their happy hour but I felt their dinner, while good, was not really a good value for the prices.

We went to the vegetarian diner. It was a nice surprise! The scramble eggs with citrus hollandaise sauce and espargus were to die for!! Everything else was pleasant but defenitly limited to what preconception of vegetation food most people have... Want to try again!

My coworkers and I visit Kaya for happy hour, occasionally.  I love the ambiance!  Brick faced walls mixed with a non-tacky tropical vibe.  It's warm and inviting - a great place to go.

I've only nibbled on a couple appetizers - Conch fritters were tasty and the black bean dip was not too bad either.  However their drinks... I have a favorite.

I've tried the Graduate which is sage liquor, limoncello, lemon, sparkling wine.  It's very fresh but a tad bit sweet.  I asked my bartender his favorite and he said the Pisco Sour - Barsol Pisco, lime, egg white*, Angostura bitters.  Frothy yet tart - I love it!  We have a winner :)

If you're looking for a great happy hour venue, try Kaya and have a Pisco Sour.  I'll be there too, so say hello!

Great brunch, even better happy hour, and always a pleasant experience. I've probably gone here 30-40 times (might have a problem), and it's consistently great. The avocado tempura tacos, fish tacos, salmon salad, and grapefuit marg are my go-tos!

It must be good if I remember eating here all these longs months latter.

I had whatever they pass off as a burger and let me tell you kids.  It was delicious.  

Highly recommend giving this place a shot.

This is my favorite Big Burrito restaurant. The place is small and funky, but never feels cramped. The food is very generous in portion size and priced fairly. You will not leave hungry. The waitstaff is very friendly and accommodating. The fish tacos were delicious and enormous.

I went with my newly Elite Yelper friend for brunch.

Tip: sign up for the big burrito group mailing list and you'll get some great coupon goodies around November December

Another tip: make a reservation using Opentable and earn points for free dining rewards 

Parking: there are the pay stations as well as pay parking by the loading docks

I had a Bloody Mary with cucumber vodka because when in Rome. It was good but I think it was on the small side and full of ice.

We split the black bean dip with homemade chips. The chips were well seasoned: salty with some subtle heat. The black bean dip was very filling and lightly seasoned. It wasn't heavy and paired so well with the chips. 

I got the veggie burrito (since it had mushrooms and seasonal veggies) but had them add the chorizo and bacon (for a few dollar up charge). This thing was gigundo! The over easy eggs were on top, so when you cut in the creamy yolky goodness cascaded down the burrito. This thing was chock full of potatoes, veggies, hunks of chorizo and pieces of crispy crunchy bacon. I used one of my BBG coupons and saved $10! I pretty much waddled out of there to do some shopping in the Strip.

The service was excellent. The restaurant was not exactly quiet and appropriate for a romantic dinner. Most food was quite good.  Unfortunately for this vegetarian couple it was disconcerting to receive the Tofu Cracklins to find out that they're deep fried in the same oil as the fish dinners. Thus our tofu tasted like fish. We also thought that there was way too much dressing on the Field Greens.

The decore was modern Caribbean the food is good the bar has a nice selection of rums to choose from. I would not call this Caribbean though I would call this modern Caribbean fusion the staff is attentive and the drinks will definitely get you turned up. I would give this place 5 stars but I did have one issue the Caribbean is relaxing and comfortable but this place missed that completely. It felt a little stuffy I really never relaxed while there. Another problem I had was the rum selection was extensive but like most places in the city they completely miss one of the best destinations in the Caribbean. The Dominican Republic. Now I have to admit because my wife is Dominican and i have been exposed to that culture the most I tend to look for those flavors and I never see it represented in Pittsburgh. But that's more of a issue with the city's Latin population not having representation then just this place. I would like the addition of brugal aejo rum

Update time!  Unfortunately, my previous rating was only updated, not upgraded.  A friend and I had intended to hit Bon Giorno for a quick bite before our Knife Skills class at In the Kitchen.  The sign on the Bon Giorno door said "Open for Dinner!"  The door was locked.  Hmmm.  We knocked, a guy came out and told us they're not open on Monday nights.  Hmmm....perhaps there should have been an asterisk with a notation to that effect?  I digress.

Anyhoo....Kaya was our fallback dinner spot.  It was pretty empty, but then it was a Monday and it was only 4:30 so that wasn't a bad sign.  Or was it?  Our movie-star-handsome-waiter highly recommended the Jamaican green curry.  I LOVE curry!  It came with saffron rice.  I LOVE saffron rice!  They could make it with shrimp.  I...well, you get the picture.  Both my dining companion and I ordered the curry - how could we go wrong?  Fail.  It was acceptable.  Period.  No punch of heat, although I'd ordered it hot.  The veggies were cut oddly with huge chunks of carrots and tiny pieces of green beans and cauliflower among other veggies making for hard carrots and the rest of the veggies overcooked and soft.  So disappointing.  My dining partner tried hers, but didn't even eat it.  Not wanting to hurt the waiter's feelings, she had him pack it up and then tossed it in the trash outside.  

I guess Fried Chicken Thursday is the night to go.  It sure wasn't Monday.  Hard to believe this is a Big Burrito restaurant.
